section.title: used to
section.sectiontitle: We use used to + verb for habits and states in the past.
section.text1a: I used to go to the gym every day.
section.text2a: My sister used to have really long hair.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use did not use to + verb. In the question, we use did + subject + use to + verb.
section.text3: He used to wear glasses. Now he wears contact lenses.
section.text3a: He didn't use to wear contact lenses.
section.text4a: Did you use to like sports at school? No, I didn't.

section.title: used to
section.sectiontitle: We use not … any longer and not … any more to say that something was true in the past but it not true now.
section.text1: I used to play volleyball but I don't play volleyball now.
section.text1a: I used to play volleyball, but I don't any longer.
section.text2: Andy used to drink coffee but he doesn't drink coffee now.
section.text2a: Andy doesn't drink coffee any more – it gives him a headache.
section.sectiontitle2: We use still to emphasise that something has not stopped or changed but continues to the present.
section.text3: I used to like the Beatles in the past and I like them now.
